statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
Andre Miller made seven free throws in the
final four minutes, including two with 35 seconds remaining that
put Los Angeles ahead to stay, and the Clippers went on to a
112-107 victory over the Sacramento Kings on Saturday night.
article.headline: Miller's free throws down stretch ice it
article.linkText: Clippers toe the line in shocker over Kings
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- The game was on the line for the Los Angeles Clippers, who won it with the help of a whopping disparity in free throws.
Miller

Andre Miller made seven free throws in the final four minutes, including two with 35 seconds remaining to put Los Angeles ahead to stay, and the Clippers went on to beat the Sacramento Kings 112-107 on Saturday night. The Clippers outscored the Kings 38-5 at the line, where Los Angeles had 46 shots and Sacramento only seven. In the fourth quarter, the Clippers went 19-of-24 from the line while the Kings' Peja Stojakovic missed his team's only free throw. Sacramento coach Rick Adelman couldn't believe it. "I've never been involved in a game where someone shoots 46 free throws and you shoot seven. I mean, I'm sorry. That's almost humanly impossible for that to happen,'' Adelman said. "When you have 15 more field goals (49-34), I don't know.'' The Clippers had averaged 27.8 free-throw attempts in previous games this season, and the Kings had averaged 23.3. Elton Brand, who went 10-for-12 from the line and scored his Clippers' high of 34 points, acknowledged that Los Angeles got the breaks. "We definitely got the calls in our favor, but we were going to the hole and they were shooting a lot of jump shots, so that helped a lot,'' Brand said. Sacramento's Chris Webber, who scored 22 points and missed his only two free throws, was particularly frustrated. "I was just trying to get to the hole, trying to get some fouls, that's all. But they didn't see them. It's 46-7 in free throws and that's ridiculous,'' Webber said. "But that's not the reason we lost. We lost because they beat us tonight. You can't cry about it.'' The Clippers' victory before a cheering, sellout crowd of 20,037 came on the heels of one of their worst games in franchise history, a 95-64 loss to the Minnesota Timberwolves on Wednesday. Miller, who made all 10 of his free throws and scored 14 points against Sacramento, played despite the death of his stepfather, Albert Robinson, a day earlier. Lamar Odom added 24 and Corey Maggette 21 for Los Angeles, which won for just the third time in 11 games. Stojakovic led the Kings, who lost for only the third time in 11 games, with 37 points on 16-of-22 shooting. Vlade Divac had 24 points and 10 rebounds, and Chris Webber had 22 points. Mike Bibby had just four points on 2-for-12 shooting, but did have 10 assists. In the loss to Minnesota, the Clippers scored the second-fewest points in franchise history and the score was their lowest since 1972, when they were the Buffalo Braves and lost 91-63 to Milwaukee. The Kings beat Dallas, which has the NBA's best record, 123-94 on Wednesday. Quentin Richardson drove for a layup to give Los Angeles a 105-101 lead with 1:33 remaining. Divac made a layup, then Webber forced Brand into a turnover and Stojakovic made a fadeaway 12-footer to even it at 105 with 49 seconds remaining. Miller then made two free throws, Stojakovic missed an open 3-point try, and the Kings were forced to foul with time running out. Sacramento's Jim Jackson, who had 10 points in 21 minutes, drew two quick technicals and got ejected when he drew a charging foul and kept yelling at referee Eddie Rush with 9:46 left. Maggette made both free throws to pull the Clippers within 86-85. The Kings, up by as much as 62-50 early in the third quarter, led 84-80 going into the fourth. Game notes
Losing for only the third time this season against a team with a losing record, the Kings dropped to 12-9 on the road. ... Sacramento F-C Keon Clark sat out the second half because of stiffness in his right ankle. ... Webber, facing additional charges for allegedly lying to a grand jury about a Michigan basketball booster, said before the game that there's nothing new in the indictment. "It's the same thing as it's always been,'' he said. The new indictment Friday charged Webber, father Mayce Webber Jr., and aunt Charlene Johnson with nine counts, including conspiracy to obstruct justice and perjury. They are accused of lying to a federal grand jury about their dealings with former Wolverines booster Eddie Martin in 1988-93.
